Episode 7 - Laythe and Vall (Part 1)    (Mar 28 - Apr 09, Mission Day 238-246)

This episode covers the landings on Laythe and Vall and the surface tour on Laythe. It took longer than expected, because IRL stuff held me back, and the game had again new (bad) surprises for me. Before this episode, I had to reload only 2 times, but on Laythe only, I reloaded 4 times, and Falcon is still sitting on the surface.
I already know, that I can't complete the mission before my vacation, when I will take a break of two weeks. It's doubtful, that I can complete my tour on Vall before it, and Jool and Tylo must wait for sure, until I'm back again. 

Overview of the situation

Spoiler

Sloth is waiting in its orbit around Tylo. Falcon is separated in Laythe orbit and ready to land. The Tree of Life has its capture at Vall in 4 days. Relay 2 has its circularization burn in 2 days, but I will do it now, because I will be busy with the other missions, and the relay constellation doesn't have to be perfect. In less than a half orbit I will complete the science collection anyway.

At Laythe

Spoiler

Bill is on EVA to prepare the aerodynamics of the Jool stage for atmospheric flight. I can't remove the decoupler, but luckily, the tube, which covered the engine, disappears when I switch to the vessel again. Putting on a nose from a fuel tank, which won't fly into an atmosphere again.


Before starting the science collection, let's take a closer look into Falcon's cargo bay. I took here a slightly different approach, than at the other vessels, which were quite minimalistic. I have four spectro-variometers, because the atmosphere analysis is biome sensitive at flight and it gives more points for multiple copies. I have four mystery goos and science jr. They are not biome sensitive in flight, but Jool has only one biome, and I will have only one shot in the low atmosphere to collect multiple copies of them. I have only one of each of the other science experiments. The thermometer is biome sensitive in flight, but it doesn't give additional points for multiple copies, so I don't need more. The seismometer and the gravimeter I can use only on the surface, where I have time to do the experiments multiple times. In the other half of the cargo bay, there are 8 RTGs, which are enough, to power the propellers on Laythe and the reaction wheels on Jool. The three reaction wheels are necessary, to give some kind of stability in space and in thin air, because the thrust isn't aligned with the center of mass. There is a container for the surface experiments. At the back, there are the four science containers, and between them, because there was some free room, three tiny fuel tanks. Jebediah is the pilot of Falcon and Bob is the scientist.


Starting the science collection with a first small dip into the atmosphere. Flying high over Sagen Sea.


As I mentioned in the last episode, I have too much fuel on board. It's not enough to reach a low circular orbit with rocket power only, I still have to aerobrake. For the burns, I use the Rapier engine only, because of the imbalance, not with full thrust, but I'm not in hurry.


At the next orbit, flying high over Degrasse Sea.


And the first aerobrake maneuver. Another one of medium intensity and two small ones will follow with retrograde burns to reach a low orbit.


Draining some fuel to reach the planned mass for the entry into the atmosphere.


Fuel transfer for the correct mass distribution. The wings are empty, the four small fuel tanks at the back too, the larger tanks on the outside are partially filled. During the tests I noticed, that the wings are a weak part of the plane. I can't remove the landing gears from the side tanks, but I can reduce the stress with emptying the fuel tanks. And overall, I have to move the center of mass to the front, to not flip at entry. I want to land at a specific place, so I have to aerobrake during the descent to adjust my trajectory. My wing area isn't sufficient to maintain level flight with 50t, and I have only limited fuel to use jet power, so I have to be really precise. I think, the landing on Laythe is the most technical maneuver, I ever did. I needed more time to develop my Jool maneuver, but the result was less complex. It doesn't look that spectacular on the video, but I will explain the background, so you get an impression about what's going on.


I practiced the landing six times before I tried it for real. The first five ended in a crash. It was the same in the test mission. When I don't do it for several weeks, I have to learn the whole procedure again. My orbit in the test mission was lower, which made it more difficult to adjust my trajectory with aerobraking. My primary landing site is the little island east of the larger one. The secondary landing site is the peninsula at the west of the larger island, where Falcon is on the screenshot. I've chosen these spots, because they are on the equator, they have nearly flat terrain, and they are on sea level, which is essential for the landing, and very useful for the start to orbit. There's over a day until the capture burn of the Tree of Life at Vall, it's enough to land.

Landing on Laythe

Spoiler

Here is the uncut video of the entire landing procedure. As always, screenshots will follow.

 

Performing the deorbiting burn at almost the opposite side of Laythe. I do the adjustments by eyeballing. As I said, my orbit in the test mission was different.


Switching to prograde direction before entering the atmosphere, when no retrograde burn is necessary anymore. The cargo bay is open to collect more science. I will fly over an island soon after entry, and can catch multiple biomes.


Flying high over Shores.


Flying high over Peaks.


Flying high over Dunes.


I missed the Shallows, but now it's time for aerobraking. During the maneuver, Falcon is tumbling quite heavy, the reaction wheels and the correct mass distribution are essential in this phase. It would be cool to look at it, but I have to control the trajectory.


Switching to prograde again before the atmosphere gets too thick. The trajectory still overshoot the island, but in the thicker atmosphere there's enough drag, which will make it shorter. I mustn't overshoot the target, because I can't do a U-turn. I would lose too much altitude to reach the island.


It starts to be hot, but there's no danger of overheating.


Draining some oxidizer to reduce mass further. The planned fuel for the ascent to orbit is 2454/2486 LF/Ox, and I want to get as close to it as possible at touchdown. I will use liquid fuel with the Rapier engine in jet mode, but I will use oxidizer only in the final seconds with the four Twitch engines. If you haven't noticed them yet, they are mounted on the bottom of the plane. With that high mass, small wings and thin air, I can't land safe like a plane, I need the chutes and the rockets.


The trajectory looks good. I won't overshoot the island. I have fuel for a few minutes of jet power to reach the target, if I'm short.


Below 300m/s, starting the engine and pointing to the island.


Below 200m/s, starting the propellers too. As the jet loses thrust with lower speed, the propellers gain thrust through the thicker air. I adjust the propeller angle, based on speed and altitude, with the H-N keys. The task is, to reach the island before running out of fuel, at an altitude of over 1000m. At practice I was short several time, so I had to switch off the Rapier engine, when ran out of fuel, and did the final part with propellers only. As I wanted to deploy the chutes, the engine switched on again, because it's in the bottom stage. To avoid this, I switched the stages before my first real landing, but then the chutes didn't deploy, even they were in the first stage. I don't know why. I had to reload, because after I pressed Space multiple times, the decouplers detached all the chutes. This is the second landing attempt.


Draining more oxidizer before the landing. Then changing the propeller angle for slow flight. This increases the thrust at slow speed, and it's an efficient air brake at higher speed.


The next critical point, the deployment of the chutes. The first four chutes fully deploy at 1000m altitude, the other ones later. But already the first brings the plane almost to an immediate stop. I have to set my trajectory right in advance, to land, where I want. At the same time, I have to slow down below 95m/s before the full deployment. At higher speed, the forces would break off the wings and the fuel tanks.


At 500m, all chutes are fully deployed, and starting the propellers again with full thrust. The landing is really on the edge. I not only need the chutes and the small rockets to land, I need the propellers too, to not crash fully vertical into the ground. The distribution of the chutes and the fuel is well planned to keep the plane horizontal at full propeller thrust, to land on all landing gears at the same time. That's the reason, why I need a flat terrain. At the test mission I was really frustrated, because I crashed every time, but I did it earlier safely. After five crashes I noticed, that two chutes were in the wrong stage and didn't deploy. That was enough to not be horizontal and unable to use the propellers, and it ended in a crash everytime.


Switching on the rockets to reduce vertical speed.


A quite rough landing. As you can see, there is very little ground clearance, so I have to use a stiff damper setting on the landing gears, which isn't helpful in this situation. The position of the bottom tanks are limited by the docking port. The position of the side tanks are limited by the length of the ladder, because the kerbals have to climb back somehow into the cockpit. The position of the rear landing gears are that high, to reduce drag at water takeoff. I didn't mention it, but I had to switch off SAS, because wit SAS on, the wings would break off.


Transferring all the fuel into the three center stacks of fuel tanks, and draining everything, what isn't necessary for the ascent.


Filling a little fuel into the tail tank for a better balance during the flight tour. A little more would be better.


I'm sure, you already noticed the hydraulic cylinders on the bottom, and meanwhile you may think, what comes next. I don't want to carry all the fuel with me during the whole tour, so I will dump it here. It's easier to fly with 15t than with 50t. I designed the plane, to fly with the reduced mass, that's the reason, why it has small wings. On Jool, I will have additional wings on the detachable first stage.


Going further away to remove the chutes. I don't want all that debris at the landing site. It's cool, how explosive those chutes are. Are they made of the same material, than the solid rocket fuel?

Laythe tour part 1

Spoiler

Starting the science collection. Landed at Shores, with flag planting and EVA experiment.


Deploying the surface experiments. I don't have the grand slam experiment here. I wouldn't get my projectile up to speed in the atmosphere, and I didn't want to develop a different one for Laythe. Falcon is already heavy enough. I have 3 RTGs, because I don't have an engineer here. Falcon has only two seats, and I need a pilot and a scientist on the mission.


Switching off the controls of the winglets on the side tanks. I will deploy them via action group. I will use them as flaps at landing and takeoff, and as hydrofoils in the water.


The landing site, before starting the tour.


Not far away, there is a boulder. I don't even have to take off. Surprisingly, I have no problems with moving vessel, unlike on Eve.


A geyser is also in sight.


Bob's taking a cold bath to collect samples from the water.


Splashed at Shores, with all the previous sites visible in the background.


It's time to go up into the air, and fly like a plane. With the hydrofoils, Falcon can glide stable on the water with 30-90m/s, and it has a minimum takeoff speed of 50m/s.


Flying low over Shores.


Flying low over Shallows.


Heading west to the bay, where my secondary landing site was. There is the first special place for science collection.


A safe landing on the water.


Splashed at Shallows.


Climbing out of the water.


Landed at Shallows.


And there is also a stone not far away, so I can get rid of the scanner arm.


I like to take off from flat terrain or from water, but downhill is also OK as long as it isn't bumpy.


Heading northwest to Crescent Bay, and taking some other biomes on the way.


Flying low over Dunes.


The first landing on land. Luckily it isn't bumpy. I soften the dampers, but if I hit a bump at around 30m/s, I get airborne again, but at that speed I can't control the plane and it most likely ends up crashing into the ground with the nose.


Landed at Dunes.


The next part of the tour goes over the sea, there's enough time to climb up high. Flying high over Shallows. I didn't want to take high atmosphere science, like I did on Eve. Luckily, it's much easier to construct a plane, which can fly up to 10km on Laythe, than one, which can reach 22km on Eve. If you remember, it took 30 days to collect space science over all biomes, and in the atmosphere I can do only 4x time warp. As I built the plane, I reached 13400m altitude, but it was with the old wings. At first, I had structural wing, but they had nearly the same size as the delta wings. I switched them, as I designed my flight on Jool. I need there more liquid fuel for the final stage. On Laythe, they were empty at the descent, and will be only partially filled at the ascent.


Flying low over Sagen Sea.


Arriving at Crescent Bay, and climbing up high again, to collect all science.


Flying high over Crescent Bay.


Flying low over Crescent Bay.


Reaching terminal velocity at the descent.


Splashed at Crescent Bay.


Heading to the north pole, to the second special place for science collection. That mountain is on the way. Perfect.


Flying low over Peaks.


I haven't practiced the landing at such a high altitude. Maybe a mistake, because the air is much thinner, but luckily, the terrain was flat, and the plane behaved really well.


Landed at Peaks.


The Tree of Life has four hours until its capture burn at Vall. The maneuver node doesn't look like it should. It should be at PE. After many bad experiences, I don't trust the game. I will pause my tour on Laythe, and focus here. I don't want to miss the Vall encounter.

At Vall

Spoiler

Capture burn at Vall.


And the circularization.


Transferring fuel to Jellyfish, and making inventory. If I have enough fuel to land Wasp on Vall and to fill Jellyfish, then I don't need a refueling mission. I want to land on the equator, and the biome constellation on Vall is like, that if I visit all the biomes, I will come back to the same place, where I started. So I wouldn't need two landings.


There's enough fuel.


I still can drain some liquid fuel, to match the level to the oxidizer.


Another fuel transfer for the right mass distribution.


Decoupling the LF tanks. Wasp uses LFOx, Jellyfish is full, and at Tylo I don't refuel the mothership, so there's no need for the tanks anymore.


That basin in the center will be my landing area.


I almost messed up the landing (I was too tired on that evening), but I survived. But I forgot to take the extra probe core to the surface. On the other moons, it wouldn't be an issue, because of the second landing, but here I don't want to land a second time.


The fuel production is running, and the surface experiments are deployed.


Meanwhile, on Laythe it's night time at Falcon's position. Because I want to fly at daylight, there is time for Projectile 3 to crash into Vall's surface.


This time, there's no reduction for the distance. Maybe, too close isn't good. But the impact energy is only 23%. It looks like, on larger bodies, a greater impact is necessary. Maybe I have to improvise something at Tylo. I didn't do this experiment on Tylo in my test mission.

Laythe tour part 2

Spoiler

Waiting for sunrise, and then flying at the terminator to the next destination.


Vall can be really huge in opposition.


The polar ice cap gets visible. I noticed here, that my course lead me to the wrong island. After it, it was clear, that I will arrive in the darkness, what I didn't want.


Flying low over Poles.


Flying high over Poles. The landing spot is on the right end of the island.


Splashed at Sagen Sea. Close to the biome border, which runs here also over the ice cap.


Splashed at Poles.


Unfortunately, I can't climb onto the ice, so I have to take off and land again, but at least, the ice is flat.


Landed at Poles with Vall at the horizon.


After rolling a little, landed at Sagen Sea.


The first two stages. But now, I will really wait for sunlight.


Meanwhile, Wasp is refueled, and it goes into hibernation.


The next stage of the tour will go over Degrasse Sea to Crater Bay. It starts to be boring. Long flights over the ocean, and I had to do them many times, because I didn't save frequently, and I had to reload multiple times for various reasons. Luckily, Falcon is much faster, than my Eve plane was. I had there much longer uninterrupted flights, but there I flew at least mostly over land. This is the last island before the open sea.


Flying low over Degrasse Sea.


Splashed at Degrasse Sea.


Flying lower with a higher propeller angle improves the speed a little. At least something positive.


After an eternity, arriving at the perimeter of the crater. Starting to climb, to get low and high atmosphere science in a single flight.


Flying low over Crater Bay.


Flying low over Crater Island.


Flying high over Crater Island.


Flying high over Crater Bay.


I managed to land exactly in the largest gap between Crater Bay and Crater Island biomes, so I had to cruise quite a lot on the water. KerbNet would be really useful here, but I can't use it on Laythe. I could glide much faster on the water, but then I have to take off, because I can't stop safely.


Splashed at Crater Bay.


At that distance, I decided to do a short flight to the island.


Splashed at Crater Island.


Climbing out of the water extreme carefully. I don't know why, but at this maneuver I had an engine failure multiple times. I thought about the reasons. Was it, because the coast is so steep, that the propellers touched the water, or because the cargo bay was open? But none of them is plausible, especially as I looked back the screenshots, and saw, that at the Shallows biome, I did the same, without consequences. With three propellers, I couldn't go straight, and if I switched off the engine on the opposite side, it was quite difficult to take off. I could fly, but with only two propellers, it's impossible to reach orbit. I had to reload. Maybe the island should be called Kraken Island.


Landed at Crater Island. The final biome.


The route at stage 3.


After a longer break, to do the final stage in daylight, leaving the island to fly back to the starting point.


After an hour long flight over the ocean, preparing for the final landing. This one is probably the most difficult, because the terrain here is quite bumpy.


The surface experiments need more time, in that I can do the tour around Vall, but that's for the next episode.


Here is the final stage of the tour. I collected splashed science from 8 biomes and landed science from 7 biomes.

Here is a short video of Falcon, which shows its flight capabilities on Laythe. The footage isn't from the actual mission.

 

Edited April 14 by DennisB

Episode 8 - The Vall Tour    (May 08-16, Mission day 246-252)

After a long break, it's time to continue the mission. I needed some extra motivation, because after driving over 5000km IRL in my car, I wasn't in the mood to drive another 1500km virtually on Vall. But now, it's completed, and the tour on Tylo will be shorter and faster. I completed already the Laythe ascent too, which I planned to include in this episode, but I decided to split it into two parts, because of the length.

Overview of the situation

Spoiler

Sloth is waiting in its orbit around Tylo. Falcon is on Laythe, waiting for the surface experiments, which need 29 days to complete. Falcon's Jool stage is waiting in orbit, together with Veterinarian.


Jellyfish is in Vall orbit, while Wasp and Tetrapus are on the surface. The surface experiments here need 51 days to complete, so the time has come for the longest tour of the mission, the tour around Vall, to visit all its biomes.

Day 1

Spoiler

Starting the science collection in the Lowlands biome, right at the landing site.


On Vall I lowered the suspension to 0,40-0,42m, much lower than on Pol and similar to Bop, and stiffened it to 150 to get better stability at higher speed and to reduce the risk of bottoming at landing after jumps.


Starting the tour at sunrise. All the surface features are present close to the landing site. At first, scanning the ice chunk.


Then the cryovolcano.


And finally, the rock. You can see, how close everything is together.


Heading to the north to get to the Northeast Basin. At the beginning, the terrain was really smooth and easy. As I developed Tetrapus, I didn't do much test runs on Vall, so I set a reference speed of 30m/s for myself. But I realized soon, that on smooth terrain I can go even faster. The only problem is braking. I needed time to get the right feeling for the terrain, where to expect dangerous jumps, because already at a slight downhill slope I need around 1km to stop from 40m/s. Yes, I could improve it by adjusting the friction level of the wheels, but I don't want to do it all the time. It's enough for me to focus on the terrain.


I didn't know, that Vall has terrain with negative elevation.


Zooming out to the maximum is the best way for me to navigate. The navigation in general is more difficult, than I expected. The surface in this view looks different to the map view, and the terrain structures, which I used to plan the whole tour, were too large to use them for orientation on the ground, so I had to zoom out regularly to control my position and course. The plan is, to go over to the right part of the basin and cross the mountain ridge on the upper right to reach the next biome.


A jump, which Tetrapus can handle safely. There will come some really bad terrain, where I had real fear to get damage, but the rover is more robust, than I thought, or I'm too careful. But I play, like I wouldn't have the option to reload.


Plan change. Instead of crossing the mountain ridge at the lowest pass, I will go up to the mountain to get the other global biomes.


Highlands. I have to use the telescope arms during the science collection, because the terrain is too slippery, and this is a good way to prevent sliding down the slope.


Reaching the Midlands biome while climbing up the mountain.


Climbing on a slope of 25° is no problem for Tetrapus.


Right at the edge of the Mountains biome there is a nearly flat plateau with a good sight to the basin, from where I came from.


There is no need to climb up further. On the other side there is already the next biome. I choose a safe route for the descent, and don't go straight down on the steepest slope.


Northeast Basin.


From here, the route goes to the east, to the Northwest Basin. It goes through a quite narrow basin, but it is still too large to see it clearly while navigating on the ground. Some landscape shots on the way.


Enterin the next basin. The surface without textures makes it more difficult to estimate the speed. The only references are the stones, but there are areas, where they are very rare.


And then, suddenly there is such a jump, where I wasn't careful enough, but luckily, I survived.


Leaving the basin, the valley gets tighter, so it's visible even from the ground.

Northwest Basin.


The plan is, to go southeast, and behind the mountain in the background turning right and head straight to the south to the Southern Basin. I wasn't sure, what to expect on that route, because there is a longer part without any large basins. And already here you can see, that the terrain isn't as smooth as it was mostly before. That means a lower speed in general and more stops for orienting.


But very soon, it was sunset. Driving to the east means shorter daylight time.


The route of the 1st day.

Day 2

Spoiler

Some landscapes at the Northwest Basin.


Trying to follow the valley to reach the next basin. You can see that straight line, which @king of nowhere mentioned too in his report. It seems, there are more of them on Vall, because this is a different one, and not the only one, which I found on my tour. At this part I get to an area for the first time, which could be called Badlands, and this was not the only time. Already with 25m/s, Tetrapus was just jumping around. As I hit such an area with 30m/s, I could only pray, because I couldn't even brake, because I touched the ground only for some moments. But Tetrapus survived this too, somehow.


Fron here, heading straight to the south. The terrain wasn't difficult from here, and even after the basins, it wasn't bad. The terrain wasn't spectacular too. I made many screenshots, but I included already many screenshots, and here aren't many things, which are worth to show.


Reaching the end of the basins, and crossing the equator, which marks half way of the tour.


The best way to navigate in this hilly area is, to use the navball and go to the south. At the end I went a little off of the course.


The Southern Basin comes in sight.


Southern Basin.


The further plan is, to go west to the next large basin, and then to the southwest to the northest point of the Poles biome, before heading north to the Southern Valley and to the landing site.


That was very smooth, and without textures and with very few surface objects. It gives a feeling of floating in space without any reference points.


On the way to the large basin with Jool rising above the horizon again.


I get more and more courageous, and maintain speed over 40m/s for longer time. It's just important to avoid the surface features.


Every large basin has an end. There is the pass, which leads to the next valley and then to my next destination. I had the hope, that it will be more interesting, than the past hours, but I couldn't imagine, what awaits me.


The route will lead me through this valley. Behind the high mountain ridge in the background should be the Poles biome. I will go around it on the left side. There is a pass visible. Then I will go further to the right (to the north) and climb over the ridge to get to the Southern Valley.


Getting to the end of the valley. That is a really high mountain.

Reaching the most southern point, and getting to the highlight of the tour. I will pass this mountain ridge on the left to reach the polar basin, and then go over it to the right to leave it again.


Poles, with a wonderful sight to the polar basin and the surrounding mountains.


What will come behind the next crest?


The way out from here leads through this valley. The end looks already from here spectacular.


I don't go down to the bottom, because I can drive well on the side too, and at the end I have to climb up again.


That looks really steep. Pushing Tetrapus to its limit, but I can't take a direct route uphill.


Reaching the pass, which marks the highest point of the tour, and looking back to the south polar region. I'm happy, that I did the tour in this direction, and had the highlight near the end, and I think, this part looks better, driving in this direction.


Looking forward to what will come next. Of course a steep descent, and endless driving in mostly flat basins.


Southern Valley, the final biome.


Going slightly downhill on the textureless surface I take less care about the speed, and get surprised, when I look at the speed.


Driving through the Southern Valley wasn't eventful. At the end, I made a mistake in the navigation, and turned to the right too early, into the small valley. As I noticed my mistake, it was too late to turn back, so I decided to go over the foothill to the side of the large valley and then to the pass.


The plan is, to go through the basin on the right side of the first mountain ridge, and climb over the second one, to reach the basin of the landing site.


If anybody wants to reach high speed without rockets, this basin is the perfect place to do it. Over 40km very smooth surface, going downhill the whole way form 2100m to 400m. I set here my Vall speed record with 48m/s, at first by accident, later intentionally.


The final hills of the tour before reaching the final basin.


Finished. There's only the docking left. I need the telescope arms here, because the gravity of Vall is too strong to lift Tetrapus with the force of the docking port only.


Here is the route of the whole tour. It took 20 hours of driving, navigating, sightseeing and collecting science, plus a night break. I'm a little surprised, that I completed it without any accidents, and without using any repair kits.

 

Edited May 26 by DennisB

Episode 9 - Leaving Laythe    (May 22-23, Mission Day 252-278)

In this episode I will finish the mission on Laythe with Falcon's ascent to orbit, which is that part of the mission with the tightest margin of all. Like for the landing on Laythe, for this one I needed many practice runs to find out the right ascend profile and when to switch the engines, because I did it almost 4 months ago for the last time. There's no situation overview necessary, because everything is like at the beginning of the last episode, so let's jump into the whole procedure, there is a lot of stuff to do.

The way to orbit

Spoiler

The surface experiments still need time, and there's nothing else to do than time warp for 22 days.


Collecting the science, but letting the equipment on the surface. It can't be used on Jool, so it would be only ballast on the rest of the mission.


To get to orbit, I need the fuel and the engine, which I detached after the landing.


Switching off two of the engines for better throttle control while maneuvering on the ground.


Here is the full uncut video of the ascent, with the preparation in 5x timelapse. As always, the screenshots with explanation will follow.

Because of the front landing gear, it's only possible to go reverse for docking, like a trucker picking up a trailer.


I tired to get the tanks as close as possible to each other to minimize misalignment, but doing the docking maneuver this way, it's impossible to avoid it completely. Luckily, on Laythe it's not so critical as on Jool, and for the docking in space I have a better construction.


Reached the right position, and the force of the docking port keeps the plane on position and helps with the alignment. A nearly horizontal terrain is essential for this.


As you can see, the hydraulic cylinders are close to their limits, like everything on this Laythe mission.


Transferring all the fuel from the side tanks of the docked stage to the other tanks. Those two tanks will stay on Laythe, together with the hydraulic cylinders and the Twitch engines, to reduce mass and drag.


Switching on the two engines again to leave the empty tanks behind.


Adjusting the fuel flow priority. At first, the wing tanks will drain, to supply the Rapier engine in jet mode. It's necessary, to reach a reasonable altitude before starting the rockets. The propellers alone can't do it with a mass of 40t. The rockets will drain the side tanks at first, then the bottom tank, and the core tanks at the end.


Stiffening the suspension for the higher mass.


Adjusting the staging, and putting every important window on the screen, while rolling to the starting point. But that's the wrong hill, so I have to do an extra turn.


Adjusting the docking port alignment. That's only a marginal adjustment, but better than nothing.


Ready for takeoff. Starting downhill to get up to speed faster. I'd like to have a runway for this, but I have only this bumpy island, which makes the takeoff a little scary.


With the combined jet and propeller power I can finally leave the ground, and start climbing to the target altitude of 8500m.


Changing the deployment direction of the flaps for aerodynamic stage separation.


At the beginning I can climb quite fast. Later, in the thinner air, it will be more difficult. The goal is, to reach 8500m as fast as possible, and then try to get the horizontal speed as high as possible, before the wing tanks get empty and starting the rockets.


Igniting the Reliant engine as the wing tanks are almost empty. I let the Rapier engine run in jet mode a bit longer, as long as the propellers provide some extra thrust, to save fuel. Here I made a mistake. I changed the propeller angle too much, so I didn't get the maximum thrust from them. In this critical moment I'm busy with keeping the plane under control and setting the right ascend angle, so I just push the N key some times to adjust the propeller angle, but I don't check the actual value. Luckily, my ascent was a little steeper than normal, and that seems to make it more efficient. But, because my wings have a significant inclination, I can't get much over 35° without flipping. I tried several engine combinations during the development. A Vector engine is just overkill for this, Nerv engines are too havy and don't have enough thrust. I tried it with two Rapiers to reach supersonic speed in jet mode, but I couldn't, and I couldn't reach orbit with the same amount of fuel. I ended up with the Reliant-Rapier combination. The Reliant engine has decent thrust and low mass, and performs well during all parts of the ascent, so it's useful on Jool too.


Decoupling the propellers at 220m/s. I don't need them on Jool, because I don't plan to slow down there more than absolutely necessary.


Climbing with an angle of 30-35° in the thicker atmosphere with slowly increasing speed. The real acceleration starts at 19000m altitude.


Decoupling the side tanks with the rear landing gears.


Going prograde to increase speed in the thinner atmosphere, else I would run out of fuel before reaching orbit.


Reducing throttle, when time to AP gets too high, and slowly pushing AP over 50km.


Decoupling the middle tank with the Rapier engine and the front landing gear. If you do the math, the remaining dV should be enough to reach orbit.


Orbit with 126m/s left. That was my second best ascent ever (my record was 134m/s). As I started practicing this recently, my first four attempts failed. Then I did four succesful attempts, until I got the confidence to do it for real.

Around Laythe

Spoiler

Falcon is really exhausted after the ascent, but it has another mission to do at Jool. Veterinarian is on the way to help.


The ascent wasn't perfect, Falcon's orbit has over 5° inclination.


Like Sloth, Veterinarian has a limited burn time of 200s with full thrust. It needs several burns to lower AP to rendezvous with Falcon.


Going suborbital for a short time. Maybe it will give the vessel recovery points for the command pod. I don't know, how the game determines the recovery points, if the vessel was in more than one situation with the same value. Veterinarian was already suborbital at Bop and Pol, and it will go suborbital at Vall and Tylo too, to bring the probe cores suborbital. It would be nice, to get the points for Laythe for the command pod, but there is a chance, that it will get the reduced points for one of the other moons.


After three more periapsis burns, going for the rendezvous.


Bill is on EVA to do some optimization. Many more will follow to get everything right for Jool. But at first, removing the seismometer, because it works only on the surface, and the storage container, because I left the surface experiments on Laythe.


Removing the ladder, to reduce asymmetric mass and drag, and there's no need for it too.


Using the final drops of rocket fuel to reduce mass further and to spare xenon. Burning only slowly, because of the imbalance.


Then slowly rising AP with the ion engines. The maximum burn time with full thrust is now over 7min, because of the additional batteries and RTGs of Falcon, but it wouldn't be efficient to burn so long. I start with 3min, and extend it later to 5min.


After 7 periapsis burns with the ion engines, setting up the rendezvous with the Jool stage.


And the necessary inclination change.


Rendezvous, but for docking, further reconstruction is necessary.


Falcon will dock with its docking port on the bottom to the Jool stage, so Veterinarian has to dock onto the top. It has additional docking ports, so one of them can be put on Falcon. And changing the position of the RCS thrusters on Veterinarian, because they were wrong since the beginning.


Putting the additional thrusters (which were in the crew containers) on Falcon, to get better control during the docking. The maneuver has to be as precise as possible, to minimize misalignment, because that hurts really on Jool.


Ready for docking. I spent much more time on this maneuver than on others. I had real trouble in the test mission on Jool, as the plane didn't work like it should, so I try to do everything, what I can, to minimize the chance for it. But that part of the mission will be most likely unpredictable.


Maybe you've noticed already the beams on the top of the Jool stage. Now it's obvious, why they are there. They will hopefully guide Falcon into the correct position. But I will only see it deep inside Jool's atmosphere, if it worked or not.


More EVA construction. Removing the beams.


Putting on a strut, to hopefully prevent the docking port from collapsing through the forces in Jool's atmosphere.


Removing the RCS thrusters from Falcon. They would just cause drag. I put them back into the crew containers, because I will need them later.


Transferring the monopropelant from Falcon to Veterinarian.


And filling up all tanks in Falcon's core.


Putting the probe core from the Jool stage into Falcon to get the recovery points for Jool atmospheric flight, and putting the other one, which landed on Laythe, on Veterinarian.


Moving the RTG from the Jool stage to Veterinarian. I produce a lot of debris on this mission, but I reuse everything, what I can, as long as I can.


The Laythe mission is completed. If my calculation is right, I collected 86,16% of the available science at Laythe. Now, everything is ready for Jool. I only have to adjust the fuel flow at the end of the transfer. But that's for the next episode.

Edited May 30 by DennisB

Episode 10 - Jool    (Jun 05-09, Mission Day 278-286)

Today we come probably to the highlight of the whole mission. There were already many missions to Jool's moons, but only a few went into Jool's lower atmosphere, and even less did it without a heatshield, so this one is something special. Because of the length of the maneuver, and a lot of trial during the development, it took quite a long time, but finally I got it to work. As I already mentioned, Laythe was more a technical challenge, while Jool is also (or probably more) a piloting challenge, because of the construction of the spaceplane.

Overview of the situation

Spoiler

Sloth is still waiting in an elliptical orbit around Tylo. Jellyfish is in Vall orbit, while Wasp and Tetrapus are on the surface. The surface experiments here need 19 days to complete. Falcon is in an elliptical Laythe orbit, ready for the trip to Jool.

The way to Jool

Spoiler

In two orbits there is a quite good transfer to a Jool orbit with a low periapsis. It's possible to do it a little cheaper with an additional Laythe gravity assist, but the difference is marginal, compared to the amount of dV, which I will spend on lowering the apoapsis.


Leaving Laythe with the separation of the first empty tanks.


Arriving to Jool only 3 hours later, and starting the braking maneuver. Of course, the two Nerv engines don't have enough thrust to do it in one maneuver, there are several periapsis burns necessary (6 minutes each). Decoupling the next empty tanks during the first burn.


The next decoupling during the 3rd burn.


Collecting the low space science at Jool. I use the science experiments on Falcon. I have to take care to execute the gravimetry scan four times, and use the magnetometer on Veterinarian, which is used only on this one occasion.


Bill is on EVA again to do some reconstruction. Detaching the magnetometer and the gravimeter, because they don't give science in Jool's atmosphere. And putting the additional probe core from the bottom to the top of Veterinarian, to avoid loosing it, when decoupling the xenon tank.


Decoupling the next empty tanks during the 4th burn.


And the next ones during the 6th burn.


After the 7th burn the apoapsis is down to 700km. The final fuel tank of the transfer stage is empty, but I keep it, because I need the second Nerv engine for the final braking maneuver. The lower wings are almost empty too. I need the remaining fuel for the atmospheric maneuvers, so it's time for some aerobraking.


But before, decoupling Veterinarian. It will wait here in orbit. Taking the docking port from Falcon back, I will need it later.


Setting the fuel flow. At first, the outside tanks will drain from the front to the back. There is a structural tube at the front. I added it during the development to make the construction long enough for the wings. Later I put a Mk1 LF tank inside it, to increase LF capacity. The inner side tanks will drain from the back to the front, because in that stage the center of mass will move upwards, and the Vector engines on the bottom want to flip the plane, and I want to counter that effect as much as possible by moving the center of mass forward. Then the central tanks will drain together with Falcon's wings (except the rear tank at the Nerv engine), to move the center of mass upwards, because the Reliant engine on the top has much more thrust, than the Nerv engine on the bottom. In this stage, the Cub engine on the bottom gives some extra upward torque, to increase stability. At the end, the tanks of Falcon's core will drain before the final tank at the Nerv engine. That will come at last, to get the center of mass closer to the Nerv engine at the final part of the ascent, when no other engine is active.


Scratching the atmosphere for the first time, and collecting the science of the upper atmosphere.


Lowering periapsis for proper aerobraking.


The first attempt isn't deep enough, but it gets deeper on every orbit.


On the 5th orbit it's deep enough, and I have to rise periapsis a little each time. The science equipment in the cargo bay can overheat easy in this position, so I have to be careful. Two more aerobraking orbits will follow before the final entry into the atmosphere. I think, it's obvious, why I had that massive transfer stage. I don't have the patience to do the whole trip with aerobraking alone.

Flying on Jool

Spoiler

Like at the maneuvers at Laythe, I needed here several practice runs too, to find out again, how to do it. After four failed attempts I had two successful flights, and I was confident, to be successful in the real mission. But there was still the uncertainty, how the plane will behave after the problems in the test mission. Now I'm almost sure, that the problems came from wrong autostrut settings and from the ladder, which I forgot to remove in the test mission, and which caused asymmetric drag and instability. The plane behaved quite well during the mission, but I messed up the first attempt. Probably I was too tired, and I had to reload once. Here is the video of the successful second attempt. As always, screenshots with explanation will follow.

My apoapsis was quite high at the entry into the atmosphere, so I wasn't sure, if it will get low enough or I need another orbit.
I have to reduce my speed by 200m/s, and I can't do it with aerobraking alone. I need the two Nerv engines to slow down enough. Because of the limited thrust, I have to maximize the burn time at the lowest possible altitude. To do this, I keep the AP at 230-270km, and start the retrograde burn after the periapsis, when I'm still in the atmosphere, but with a significant climbing rate. This way I can reduce PE to -145km already, when I reach apoapsis at 199km. I couldn't do it, starting from a low circular orbit. It would end in a higher speed, because I have to finish the retrograde burn at 193km, and switch to the entry position to not burn up in the atmosphere. If I would do the retrograde burn at a higher apoapsis, it would end in a steeper descent, which can cause overheating too.


Below 5470m/s it's safe. It's time to decouple the empty tanks with the second Nerv engine, and switch to entry position.


Let's talk a little about action groups. I used them already during the entire mission, but especially on Jool, I use many of them. With '1' I can switch the Vector engines on and off, with '2' I can switch the Nerv engines on and off, with '3' I can switch the Nerv engines between main throttle control and independent (full) throttle, with '7' I can switch the Reliant engine on and off, with '8' I can switch the Cub engine on and off, with '9' I can deploy the control surfaces for aerodynamic stage separation, and with '0' I run the science experiments.
SAS can keep Falcon stable during the whole descent, until it slows down to transsonic speed. It's just important to keep the pitch angle around 30°. At lower angle the nose cones can overheat, at higher angle the science experiments in the cargo bay can overheat. Reaching maximum heat at 168km altitude. Between 160 and 170km the atmosphere is dense enough for Falcon to generate lift at hypersonic speed, so it can decrease speed further, before falling deeper into the atmosphere.


The next critical point is, where I switch from the entry position to a diving position at around 720m/s. I'm not a pilot, so for me it would be intuitive to switch into a slow descent earlier with a higher speed, to reach the target altitude with the right speed and a small angle, to reach level flight with minimal effort. But Falcon gets unstable, if I hit the thicker atmosphere with too high speed, and it stalls, if I try to orient it horizontal too early, and I loose too much speed at the end to catch it. The right way is, to let it flip down to -10° pitch to keep the speed stable, and catch it right before reaching 120km altitude. This way it has the highest speed at level flight, which is essential for the first part of the ascent.


At 125km, starting to slow down the descent, which is meanwhile really fast. Now it starts to be difficult. I think the air is too thin and the speed is too high to stay stable at such a radical maneuver.


At 121,5km, managed to slow down the descent, but I still have to go down 1500m. If I do it too slowly, I will lose too much speed.


At 120,6km, starting the final maneuver and switching on the Nerv and the Cub engines. They don't have enough thrust to keep up the speed at level flight, but especially the Cub engine helps to pitch the plane up, because it's below the center of mass, and with its high gimbal range, it gives a little additional stability.


At 119,8km and at almost level flight, executing the science experiments in the low atmosphere.


And Bob does his stunt again, and takes an EVA report.


Starting the Vector engines, and trying to reach a stable flight position with 30° pitch to get out of the thicker atmosphere. The gimbal range of the Vector engines is 15% to avoid oscillation with SAS.


Throttling down as the outer tanks get empty. The atmosphere is still too thick. I don't want to burn fuel from the next stage, while I have the extra mass and drag of the wings and the empty tanks attached. But I will decouple them only later, because I want to use the lift of the wings a bit longer, and the decoupling is unsafe at this altitude anyway, because the lift of the wings would let them flip upwards, and they would rip off the wings of Falcon's core. The loss of the wings wouldn't be a disaster for the aerodynamics, but I would lose 600 units of liquid fuel, which I need in the final stage, to circularize the orbit with the Nerv engine.


Switching to prograde for the stage separation over 150km. The deployment of the control surfaces looks strange. I don't know why, but with this setting the chance of ripping off the wings is the lowest.


Switching on the Reliant engine and switching off the Cub engine. After most of the aerodynamics got lost, the reaction wheels can only barely keep the plane stable while the two Vector engines and the Reliant engine push with full thrust. This part of the flight I don't control manually. This is one of the reasons, why I needed that steep ascent with the first stage, else I would fall back again with the second stage. It's obvious, and I've mentioned it already, that the center of mass is moving away from the center of thrust in this stage, and the plane wants to pitch up more and more. I start with full thrust, but I have to reduce the thrust while the fuel is burning. To avoid flipping, I watch the navball, and I reduce the thrust immediately, when the orientation starts to leave the circle of the prograde symbol. I switched off the Cub engine, because the plane wants to flip, and more thrust on the bottom would make this even worse.


As you can see, the LF and Ox weren't used equally. I will decouple the tanks with the remaining liquid fuel as soon as they are empty of oxidizer. I want to get the most dV out of the third stage, and that's the case, when it's full with fuel without extra mass. There are still additional 3000m/s necessary to reach orbit, and I need the thrust of the Reliant engine as long as possible, because the Nerv engine alone is too weak to reach orbit from here, so I wouldn't benefit from the extra liquid fuel.


The next stage separation. Till now, the plane wanted to pitch up, now it wants to pitch down, because the Reliant engine is over the center of mass. As the fuel burns, it will be better. For a better handling I switch on the Cub engine again. Both will burn on full thrust until the oxidizer runs out. Because the plane wants to pitch down, I will fly from here mostly manually again, to push the trajectory out of the atmosphere, and circularize the orbit at the end with the Nerv engine.


No oxidizer left. The Nerv engine has to do the remaining 1100m/s. The handling changes again, the plane wants to pitch up again.


Switching to prograde when I'm confident to reach orbit that way.


Orbit. That was a really good ascent, and there's also some fuel left.


The science collection at Jool is completed. If my calculation is correct, I collected 96,33% of the available science at Jool. Falcon also finished its mission. It collected 222 individual science reports, 156 2nd, 3rd and 4th copies and 53 5th copies. I don't want to spoil the next episode, so stay curious.

 

Edited June 12 by DennisB

Episode 11 - The Grand Reunion    (Jun 14-16, Mission Day 286-312)

The vessels and the crew are still spead out in the Jool system. Now it's time to reunite them, and fit together the pieces of the Tree of Life, or at least, the remaining parts of it.

Overview of the situation

Spoiler

Sloth is still waiting in an elliptical orbit around Tylo. Jellyfish is in Vall orbit, while Wasp and Tetrapus are on the surface. The surface experiments here need only a few days to complete. Falcon is in a low Jool orbit with just a little fuel left, which isn't enough to go anywhere. Veterinarian is also in low Jool orbit to "help".

At Jool

Spoiler

Falcon's flight in Jool's atmosphere wasn't perfect. It reached orbit, but because of the instability during some parts of the ascent, it has now 3° inclination.


Because of its limited burn time, Veterinarian needs three burns to adjust the inclination.


Just a nice shot with the three large moons.


Then adjusting PE.


Finally, lowering AP to get a rendezvous with only one more burn.


Three days and several orbits later.


Unfortunately, there's no need for Falcon anymore, so it's time for autopsy or transplantation or recycling or however you would call it, what comes next. At first, Bob brings the science from Falcon's cabin to Veterinarian's, and takes his new seat in one of Veterinarian's crew containers, together with Jebediah.


Let's take a look into Falcon's cargo bay. What is useful of that stuff?


The science containers of course, with all the science, and the probe core for the recovery points. But there are the reaction wheels, the battery and the RTGs too, which can be recycled. And this is, how it looks after the first part of the reconstruction.


Moving the Cub engine out of the way. There's no oxidizer in the tank, so it's useless. But I want to use the remaining liquid fuel.


Moving the docking port further back to dock with the LF tank. As you can see, there's a decoupler to separate it from the rest of the tank.


Decoupling the fuel tank from Falcon's core, and taking the docking ports. This wasn't part of the original mission plan, but as I mentioned already, I have to improvise some spacecraft at Tylo, and I need some docking ports for it.


Decoupling the empty fuel tank too.


Moving the reaction wheels onto the LF tank. It's obvious, that the thrust isn't balanced. That's the reason, why I need those reaction wheels, to be able to use more than minimum thrust of the Nerv engine.


Using the remaining liquid fuel to rise apoapsis and get rid of the inclination.


Unfortunately, I miscalculated my dV budget. There's still 0,5° inclination left, but I can correct it with a Laythe gravity assist.


Undocking the empty tank with the Nerv engine, but keeping the docking port.


Moving the RCS thrusters forward, to keep them after decoupling the first xenon tank.


The transfer maneuver to Vall with a Laythe gravity assist. I will perform it in three parts. With the additional battery and RTGs, Veterinarian can burn now 7,5min with full thrust, instead of 3,5min.


The final transfer burn with the decoupling of the first empty xenon tank.


Passing Laythe, with the next destinations in sight.

At Vall

Spoiler

That's perfect timing. Short before Veterinarian is arriving to Vall, the surface experiments have finished.


Setting the fuel flow priority of Wasp. The large tanks on the top will drain at first, then the smaller one below it, and then the rest from the outside to the center.


Time for launch.


I can't remember, if I've ever done a direct rendezvous after the launch from a larger body. This time, I was really close to do it.


Doing some ISRU on the way, because the ore tanks are full.


Decoupling the large fuel tanks. I don't need them at Tylo. The remaining fuel should be enough, and any additional mass would make the landing more difficult.


The docking with Jellyfish marks the end of the Vall mission. If my calculation is right, I collected 96,79% of the available science at Vall, if I get the recovery points for the probe core, or 96,54%, if not.


Filling the fuel tanks to the top.


The capture maneuver exceeds Veterinarian's burn time limit. But, since Sloth's capture maneuver at the same place, we all know, how to do it. This time, it will be much easier, because of the additional RTGs, the persistent thrust is around 50% instead of 10%.


A Tylo eclipse by Vall.


Starting the capture burn with persistent thrust 9min before PE, with some radial component to keep PE over the surface.


Retrograde burn with full thrust around periapsis.


And with persistent thrust again, to complete the capture.


Matching the inclination and PE.


And setting up a high speed rendezvous. Meanwhile I have enough experience in that stuff, that a rendezvous with 130m/s intercept speed with ion engines isn't more difficult than usual.


Docking with the right docking port to not damage the RTGs.


Putting the two used probe cores and Bob into Cocoon, and an unused probe core into Veterinarian, to get it suborbital around Vall. Jebediah is the poor guy, who will stay in the single seat cabin for the rest of the mission.


Veterinarian is on the way to go suborbital.


And back again.


The transfer maneuver to Tylo. That's really cheap. It needs just a little bit more than escaping Vall, and I'm already in Tylo's SOI.


During the escape burn, with the Nerv engines and the RTGs I can run the ISRU persistent, to refine the remaining ore to liquid fuel.

At Tylo

Spoiler

Capture burn at Tylo. Unfortunately, I couldn't enter into an orbit with the same orientation to Sloth's.


Sloth still has a burn time limit of 200s, so it will need several burns to reach low orbit. I calculated the maneuvers to rendezvous in high orbit, but it would cost the same. Looking back, the cheapest maneuver would've been, to send Sloth back to Vall and rendezvous there.


Entering low Tylo orbit.


Adjusting Slot's orbit to match inclination.


And PE altitude.


After two more periapsis burns, setting up the rendezvous.


Bill is on EVA again to put the science containers from Veterinarian onto Sloth.


Then putting the science reports from Veterinarian's command pod into Sloth's, and all the other science reports into the four science containers. There's no need for the other four anymore, aswell as for Sloth's antenna.


There's only one moon left, it will come in the next episode.

My Tylo tour doesn't go well. It turned out, that my rover isn't strong enough for Tylo. I had already some explosions, and lost several hours of driving, because I still don't save often enough, and if I load the autosave, it loads the moment immediately after the crash. Now I'm sure, that I can't complete the mission before my vacation, so there will come some weeks of silence here. I will complete the mission for sure, but I'm a little sad, that I can't do it in a manner, like I wanted, and like I did my Eve mission. Before Tylo, I reloaded only 7 times, and only 3 of them were because of my fault. From now, I have to drive very careful or reload more often.

Before Tylo, I reloaded only 7 times, and only 3 of them were because of my fault. From now, I have to drive very careful or reload more often.

it doesn't matter how safe your rover is. never let more than 15-20 minutes pass between saves. something i learned through painful experience.

the problem is, if your rover is safe and sturdy, you'll just go faster. you'll keep going faster until you wreck it.

it's called risk compensation. 'Booth's rule #2' states that "The safer skydiving gear becomes, the more chances skydivers will take, in order to keep the fatality rate constant", and it clearly applies also to driving rovers.

I test out the limits of all my vessels, but it looks like, I didn't test driving on Tylo enough. But now, I have to deal with it.
